buttondown.name: buttondown
buttondown.author: Ryan Gray
summary: A Markdown HTML output CSS stylesheet with
emphasis on Pandoc HTML output

github-otsaloma.name: github (otsaloma)
github-otsaloma.author: Osmo Salomaa, adapting Sindre Sorhus
summary: A minimalist attempt to replicate the GitHub Markdown
style when converting Markdown text to HTML format,
based on the github-markdown-css ptoject by
Sindre Sorhus. Adapted by Osmo Salomaa to work with
Markdown and Pandoc, and the styles of some elements
have been tweaked to suit his use cases
and personal taste.

jez.name: jez
jez.author: Jake Zimmerman
summary: Using Pandoc Markdown with Tufte CSS
note: css file is amalgam of four style files
from project - see file comments for details

killercup.name: killercup
killercup.version: 3 July 2013 (mod date of file in downloaded zip)
killercup.author: Pascal Hertleif
summary: Make Pandoc HTML documents look more awesome

manuelp.name: manuelp
manuelp.author: Manuel Paccagnella
summary: CSS stylesheet for readable pages, built for HTML
generated by Pandoc

pan-am.name: pan-am
pan-am.author: Benjamin Woodruff
summary: Simple CSS for stand-alone Pandoc documents
that serves as a good default, and should
work with markdown, reStructuredText, textile,
LaTeX, MediaWiki markup, or any other format
Pandoc supports. It should even work for
semantically structured HTML5 documents, if they're
written well enough. Webfonts are loaded through
Google's Webfonts service. Wide responsive margins
are used with justified text. Experimental CSS4
hyphenation is used on browsers that support it,
reducing the effects of rivers.

posaune.name: posaune
posaune.author: Jeriel Jan del Prado
summary: A pandoc stylesheet that gives your Markdown files a nice
and fresh look that's friendly for a single webpage
and in PDF

tufte-nikoheikkila.name: tufte (nikoheikkila)
tufte-nikoheikkila.author: Niko Heikkil√§
summary: CSS stylesheet for HTML based on
Edward Tufte's print style

tufte-otsaloma.name: tufte (otsaloma)
tufte-otsaloma.author: Osmo Salomaa, adapting David Liepmann, adapting Edward Tufte
summary: The Tufte CSS project is an attempt by David Liepmann
to adapt the design principles used by Edward Tufte
in producing printed material for use in styling HTML
for the web. Adapted by Osmo Salomaa to work with
Markdown and Pandoc, and the styles of some elements
have been tweaked to suit his use cases
and personal taste.
